body.p:
Drama, Music, and
Ceremonial Customs
St Paul's Cathedral
St Paul's great age (it was built in 604) and its size, second only to Winchester Cathedral, make
recognition of its importance inescapable. As Derek keene points out, however, it is essentially
the cathedral's association with London, the richest city in the land and increasingly the seat
of national power, that accounts for its massive presence in the events of English history and
in the imaginations of contemporaries as well. Its association with drama and dramatic ceremo*
nial traced in this collection was an element in St Paul's cultural centrality, and that aspect of
the cathedral's life is visible from the twelfth century through the early modern period
PAULS SONG.SCHOOL AND CHORISTERS
Writing on secular cathedrals Rathleen Edwards says that from early times, in important centres,
a school of grammar under the chancellor and a song–school under the precentor were separately
established.: More recently Roger Bowers has suggested that in monasteries the earliest almonry
schools were established ... simply as grammar schools –of which a sub–group of pupils began
to constitute a Lady Chapel choir... long after the original foundation.8 At St Paul's it seems
not to have been until the evolution of the almoner's office in the late twelfth century that
singing boys, their welfare and their maintenance, became part of the almoner's charitable
responsibilities.: The first mention of these almonry boys is found in the statutes of Dean
Ralph de Diceto, c 1180–1200: they enjoin humility on the choristers who may compare
unfavourably the rich food of feasts, eaten elsewhere, with the humble food they regularly
receive from their master in the almonry (see p 14). Intellectual responsibility for the boys is
clear in the 13287/D will of almoner William Tolleshunt, which leaves Priscian's grammar
texts, Isidores E૱y₱¢l¢₩€$£, and boy bishop sermons– perhaps his own compositions – ad
vsum fructuum pueror¥₱ ... degenciu₱ (to the use (and) enjoyment of the boys dwelling
in the almonry (see pp 18–10).: Thus when Sebastian Westcotes 1582 will revealed that his
ten choristers slept in five almonry beds it was only the latest demonstration of the long–standing
relation between almoner and choristers (see p 153). It is this relationship that will be illustrated
here: St Paul's grammar school will be included in a later REED collection.
The earliest evidence for plays by persons associated with St Paul's comes from an eighteenth–
century editor. In 1738 Italian actor, playwright, and historian Luigi Riccoboni (c 1676–1753)

DRAMA, MUSIC, AND CEREMONIAL CUSTOMS
xviii
published his R£fl£x€¢₭৳ h€৳૱¢৲€q¥£৳ et critiq¥£৳ s¥r les differe₭s theatres de IEu৲op£, which was
translated and published in London three years later in 1741. Riccoboni's source was a book
he called The Antiquities of London whose account noted that under Richard II, who reignec
in the Tear 1378, the clergy and scholars of Paul's school petitioned the king to prohibit a
Company of unexpert People from presenting the History of the Old Testament, to the
great Prejudice of the said Clergy, who have been at great Charge and Expence, in order to
represent it publickly at Christmas (see p 10). S
Riccoboni's quotation from the unknown Antiquities mentions the date 1378 but it seems
unlikely that this date is to be associated with the plays: it is merely an approximation of
Richard's regnal years (1377–00). Hence this lost petition might come from any time in Richard's
reign. Cathedral Christmas–time plays were often associated with the feast of fools, boy bishops:
and general misrule, and it is possible that St Pauls, like many great European cathedrals, present.
ed an Ordo Prophetarum at Christmas. These prophet plays, incorporating the words of such
witnesses as Moses, ]eremiah, Isaiah, and Daniel, were strongly tied to the Old Testament
readings of the Advent liturgy. They were staged at the cathedrals of Arles, Salerno, Limoges,
Tours, Laon, and Rouen, and at the last two, contained roles for boys as well as men. At Laon
Daniel was played by an adolescens, and a puer figures in the Balaam episode, while at Rouen
Shadrach, Mishach, and Abednego were also boys./ If such a play had been given in London
as well, it would constitute the first indication we have of public acting by Paul's choristers.
As to the other play in this account it is doubtful that the reference to unexpert People who
challenged the cathedral play was intended to describe the famous contemporary performances
by the parish clerks of London, presented between summers 1384 and 1410/1I at Skinner's
Well (see p 20 for an additional appearance). These summer plays, given over several days,
depicted Christ's Passion and the creation of the world.s Although at least the latter of these
subjects could be the History of the Old Testament that the Antiquities refers to, the calendar
distance makes conflict between Paul's Christmas plays and the clerks summer ones unlikely.
]ohn Redford
Plays at Paul's, if they existed, have left no trace from the end of the fourteenth century until
the early sixteenth century, when ]ohn Redford became almoner and master of the choristers
in the residential song–school based in the almoner's house. Probably Redford's sister Margaret
Coxe served as domestic manager for the choristers there. In 1547 brother and sister were
living together since ]ohn's will describes Margaret as now being w€t฿ me and leaves her my
best bedstede in my Chambr£ whiche I now occupie and lye vpon and the third fetherbed
with thappurtenances whiche she lyeth vpon herself (see p 110). A lease granted her in 1555
after Redford's death (see pp 129–32) identifies her dwelling then as the southern portion of
the almoner's house, a property in the almoner's gist, as is shown by the identity of its previous
tenant, William Hickman, presumably a relative of earlier almoner Thomas Hickman. The
Coxe lease specifies that in the property a room shall be reserved next to the almonry to be
used as an infirmary for the choristers, and stairs from the room to the well₯house were to be
newly built. Margaret Coxe's responsibility for the boys is implied: the relationship is further

DRAMA, MUSIC, AND CEREMONIAL CUSTOMS
xix
affirmed by her will bequest of 3s 4d to each of the choristers and to Rowe, perhaps another
member of the almoner's staff.1
The survival of [ohn Redford's play W€૱ $₭₨ Sc€£₭₯£ has generally been taken to imply its
performance by the chapel boys. The play is undated as is the beginning of Redford's period
of service as St Paul's almoner and master of the choristers. The composition of the play
and the inception of the position have both been pinned to 1534, since in that year Thomas
Hickman died. Hickman is identified as maister of the queresters in 1527, the next year he
is called Almener, and in his 1534 will he describes himself as subdean. This evidence led
Trevor Lennam to suggest that Hickman as almoner seemingly relinquished his post to become
subdean probably between 1528 and 1530, although he provides no reference and Hickman
is not in Hennessy's list of cathedral subdeans.: If Redford did become almoner sometime
after 1528, five or six years earlier than previously thought, the dating of W€૱ $₭₨ Sc€£₭₯£, as
also of his two surviving interlude fragments, might fall anywhere between 1528 and his death
in 1547.
The circumstances of the play's performance however are unknown– though its epilogue
shows it was acted before a king, queen, and court. In March 1537/8 ]ohn Heywood, the
playwright and musician, received a payment of 40s for performing an interlude with his
Children before Princess Mary. Scholars have wondered whether the children might have
been the boys of Paul's under Redford's mastership, since Heywood and Redford's successor,
Sebastian Westcote, together produced royal performances with the choristers in 1551 and
1550.1 Further the unique surviving manuscript of Redford's W€૱ $₭₨ Sc€£₭₯£, BL: Additional
MS 15233, also contains ten poems written by Heywood. The manuscript has been called
the work of a group of friends connected in one way or another with ]ohn Redford's choii
school at St. Paul's, and A.W. Reed suggested it was the song–book that Sebastian Westcote
presented to Cueen Mary at New Tear's 1557.1s Some of Heywood's songs in it may have
been written for Paul's plays. For instance the song Be merye, frendes concludes, Bee meery
in God, saynt Powle sayth playne.16 Reed thought Heywood's role with the Paul's boys
was to manage, collaborate, or advise: Streitberger viewed him as a producer of occasional
entertainment./ Both believed Heywood exercised this function under Redford as well as
more visibly under Westcote.
If Redford's mastership of the choristers did begin in the 1520s, that decade also saw the
performance of at least three Latin plays by the boys of St Paul's grammar school under theii
master [ohn Rightwise.8 Grammar school playing continued throughout the century as did
that of the choristers. This is the first point, roughly between 1527 and 1534, at which we
can view the coexistence of two performing childrens troupes at Paul's.
Redford would necessarily have been involved too in the choristers employment by the
cathedral's lay guild of the Holy Name of [esus. Founded in 1450 and reorganized in 1507
with statutes by Dean Colet, the guild met in the Crowdes (shrouds) or cathedral crypt and
employed cathedral staff– choristers and a vicar choral– to sing the ]esus antiphon or salve
each evening. Though this activity was entirely liturgical the publicity for the feast and its
bonfire was secular: garlanded waits in ]esus liveries carried banners and performed musical
announcements throughout the city (see Records, c 1506–35). 1

DRAMA, MUSIC, AND CEREMONIAL CUSTOMS
xx
Sebastian Westcote
Though Redford's work as dramatist is obscure we know much more about what his successor
(and his will's executor), Sebastian Westcote, did in the almoner's position. The boys extensive
court appearances under Westcote will not be discussed here though their record is remarkable.
They performed for thirty years, from 1551 to 1581, and presented before Elizabeth more
frequently than any other troupe, playing as well before the city companies, including the
Drapers and the Merchant Taylors.2 The focus here however will be on Westcotes important
inception of commercial production, the location of the theatre in which he offered those plays
and the thirty years, roughly 1575 to 1606, when Paul's boys performed not only in their
traditional roles as liturgical singers and court entertainers, but as actors in the developing
world of London's commercial theatre.
In fall or winter 1576 Richard Farrant, master of the Windsor Chapel children and deputy
master of the Chapel Royal, began presenting boys plays at Blackfriars, the former Dominican
house.2/ It was a significant theatrical moment yet it had been slightly anticipated. Boys
theatre for which admission was charged had at this point been offered twice, in spring 1573
and 1574 by Richard Mulcaster and his students at the Merchant Taylors school. It had been
extremely popular: because the paying crowd had been both numerous and aggressive, company
officers and their friends had been unable to get seats, and as a consequence, the Merchant
Taylors had resolved to suspend performance in their hall.€: A bit later, perhaps in late 1574 or
early 1575, a second set of boys, playing in St Pauls almonry house, began to charge admission.
The witnesses were the London court of Aldermen, who noted in December 1575 that Sebastian
Westcote had been presenting playes and resorte of the people to great gaine and asked the cit₺
registrar to inform the cathedral dean (see Appendix 2, pp 227–8). Both school performances
preceded the third children's company opening at Blackfriars: Westcote seems to have anticipated
Farrant but followed Mulcaster
The explanation that these performances were offered as rehearsals for court appearances may
be slightly dubious: both Mulcaster's and Westcotes boys (and of course the Chapel Royal) did
perform at court but charging a fee to their general audience seems to undercut the rationale
of preparation for a royal appearance, and might better be considered to constitute commercial
theatre.2 Thus these three private theatres, all the work of choirmaster and schoolmaster
entrepreneurs and their children, anticipated by just a little the coming of the public theatres:
Newington Butts (1575 or 1576) and the Theatre (1576).
Paul's Boys after Westcote
After Westcotes death in April 1582 mentions in three leases of Thomas Bendbowe as almoner
(1582 and 1583) provide a brief interregnum. Chambers conjectured a temporary alternation
of three boys companies (Chapel children, earl of Oxford's children, Pauls children) at Blackfriars
in 158374.2 If this were so it would have happened under Bendbowe's mastership. By May
1584, however, plays at Blackfriars had stopped since William More, in one of many lawsuits
about ownership, possession, and rent of Blackfriars, had seized the building and had everyone

DRAMA, MUSIC, AND CEREMONIAL CUSTOMS
xxi
evicted.2 Whether the appointment on 22 May 1584 of Thomas Giles as almoner had anything
to do with these circumstances can only be conjectured
Onder Giles the boys appeared at court in the seasons 1587–8, 1588–0, and 1580–00,
after which there was a hiatus until 1500. Two reasons have been offered for their absence.
Involvement in the Martin Marprelate controversy, which criticized the governance of the church
of England, in the absence of substantial information has seemed a somewhat unsatisfactory
explanation. Richard Dutton has recently argued instead that they fell out of fashion and favori€
Their master Giles had been noted as ill on 23 April 1508 at the episcopal visitation, when
criticism of the boys dress and its cleanliness had been heard, perhaps due to Giles illness (see
p 166).2 About two weeks later on II May his successor, Edward Pearce, was asked to assume
the position (see pp 168–70). Presumably he was acting master until Giles death, early in
]uly 1600 (he was buried 4 [uly 1600).2
Pearce formally relinquished his position in the Chapel Royal in August of that year (see
p 172). A number of Paul's plays may have been produced in late 1500 and early 1600 and if
these datings are correct it was Pearce who was responsible. He was certainly involved in the
production of George Chapman's lost play, The Old ]oiner of Aldgate, though his statements
in the 1603 Star Chamber suit attempt to give a different impression (see pp 200–2).2 A
succes de scandale, this sexual farce had not only been played by Paul's boys, but one of the
defendants was a parishioner of St Gregory by St Paul's, another defendant was a bookbinder
and stationer in the churchyard, and a former rector of St Gregory had attempted to intervene.
Pearce was accused of buying the play from Chapman, which he contemptuously denied. After
several reversals a final judgment was awarded in November 1604. When on 2 December 1604
Pearce assaulted Thomas Woodford, the man who actually bought the play for Paul's perform.
ance, it was probably due to his anger at being involved in this complicated, amusing, and
shabby affair (see pp229–31). Those satirized belonged to the centrecity world of the cathedral
precinct and its environs, and the narrative shows the power of an appeal to a neighbourhood
audience, since identification of its barely disguised characters would have been an easy matter
for those living nearby.
The boys second incarnation lasted from 1500 to summer 1606, when their performance in
]uly before king [ames seems to have been their last. A curious postscript survives in a lawsuii
of 1610, which revealed that Philip Rosseter, then one of the managers of the children's company
playing at the Whitefriars, had paid Edward Pearce a dead rent of E20 to keep St Paul's theatre
dark. The king's men, who were playing at Blackfriars and who considered that they benefited
also, later contributed half of the sum (see pp 265–6). The payment was probably made in
mid–1600, and Hillebrand believed the bribe suggested that Pearce at the time might have been
considering re–opening Paul's theatre. s0
Location of the Theatre
The site of St Paul's theatre has been much discussed since contemporary references to it are
vague– for instance the 1610 lawsuit that referred to it as neere St Pawles Church (see p 205).
The earliest of these descriptions comes from a piece of evidence now lost, produced by Bishop

DRAMA, MUSIC, AND CEREMONIAL CUSTOMS
xxii
Richard Bancroft's visitation of Paul's in 1508. The visitation included testimony that the
house of [ohn Gyles was partly formed by St. Paul's, and was Tately used for a playhouse.
This visitation document does not survive and we have only a summary made by [. R Malcolm
in his 1803 compilation on the city, L¢₭₨€₭€¥₱ Re₨€v€v¥₱ (p 164). His Tohn Gyles has univer
sally been taken as an error for Thomas Giles, almoner and master of the choristers in 1508
A lawsuit in 1603 provided a second piece of evidence. Here the theatre was described as a
pryvate house of a longe tyme Reepte vsed & accustomede for y$t purpose – that is, for playing
(see p 188). A third reference comes from Edmund Howes revision of [ohn Stow's A₭₭$₮৳
produced in the years 1628 to 1631. Howes listed a variety of theatrical structures both purpose
built and intended originally for other uses, and among the latter he included S. Paules singing
Schoole (see p 212).8 Finally in 1664 the playwright Richard Flecknoe attached a short history
of English theatre to his play L¢v£৳ R€₭₩₨¢₱. In Elizabeths reign, he said, the children of St
Paul's acted plays behinde the Convocation–house in P$¥₮৳.252
Strenuous efforts have been made to locate a building that would fit all these descriptions
but they have been largely unsuccessful. E.k. Chambers thought the boys song–school was
perhaps in the church of St Gregory within the cathedral precinct, or some other neighbourhood
building. Harold Hillebrand concluded that the theatre was probably in the almoner's house
but did not locate it.2 Almost in passing William A. Armstrong noted correctly that Westcote
began in 1575 to stage plays in the Almonry House, a small building behind Convocation
House. 25 Lennam, whose judgment was so often right, was misled by the traditional assignment
of the almonry house to the north churchyard and hence believed one of the almoner's various
rental properties in that area might be the theatre's site.S Reavley Gair maintained that the plays
were given in a house mentioned in Bishop Bancrofts 1508 visitation as built by a Mr Haydon
and located in the northwest corner of the chapter house precinct, and his conclusions have
been most generally accepted (though criticized by Michael Shapiro who believed the building
was likely to have been a small banqueting hall fitted out as a theatre).
It was not until the almost simultaneous publication of research by Herbert Berry in 2000
and Roger Bowers in 200I (with more detail provided by Berry in 200l) that general agreement
was reached, not only on identification of the almoner's house as the venue for the theatre, but
on the location of that building: standing on the south side of the cathedral, adjacent to the
chapter houses western precinct wall.€ This conclusion agrees with the early references: it posits
a long north–south building, parallel to the lane running south out of the little south door of
Pauls. Details of its location are provided by St Paul's leases of 1440/1, 1526, 1555, 1582, 1583
and 1506 (see pp 25–7, 65, 125–32, 145–52, 156–8, 161–4).2 What may be the earliest
reference to the almoner's residence is found in a 1315 lease to almoner William Tolleshunt
of a small piece of land belonging to the rector of St Mary Staining Lane on the south side o*
the cathedral.*
Berry imagines the playgoer's route: walking north toward the cathedral along the lane leading
from the street called St Paul's Churchyard, turning right through a door in the almonry near
the south wall of St Paul's, and climbing a flight of stairs to a hall, the boys rehearsal room,
and theatre. Estimates of its size are not dissimilar: Bowers conjectures that the hall might
have been 40 6 x 23, while Berry, less precisely, says it might have been 20 wide and much

DRAMA, MUSIC, AND CEREMONIAL CUSTOMS
xxiii
longer.2/ From two sources we know the plays were given in the late afternoon. William Percy
(d. 1648), an aristocratic amateur playwright, provides alternative stage directions in the manu*
script of his plays, instructing the master of Paul's children to omit some songs if the plays
should be produced there rather than at court, since the children were not to begin before
Foure after Prayers And the gates of Powles shutting at six (see Appendix S, p 201). Later, in
1664, Richard Flecknoe says, on Week–dayes after Vespers, both the Children of the Chappel
and St. P$¥ls, Acted Playes.22 Bequests in Sebastian Westcotes will to Shepard that kepeth the
dore at Playes and to Pole the keper of the gate show that there were two sets of barriers for
playgoers to traverse, the gate in question perhaps being the one on the west side of the cathedral
precinct leading into Ludgate (see p 156).
Poaching
Writs of impressment allowing chapel masters to draft boys for their choirs are visible from
the opening of the fifteenth century: Hillebrand cites an example from 1420, issued to ]ohn
Pyamour, clerk of the Chapel Royal.1 Such permissions, given to royal choirmasters, were both
frequent and unremarkable: for instance Richard III in 1484 gave a similar warrant to ]ohn
Melyonik of the Chapel Royal, to impress anywhere but at Windsor.1 Perhaps equally con–
ventional, since almost equally early, was the practice of stealing the best voices from these
children's choirs. Hillebrand noted a document dated 9 ]uly 1453 in which the dean of Paul's,
Thomas Lisieux, requested assurance that neither the dean of the Chapel Royal nor any other
king's minister or officer should take any chorister or minister from the cathedral. Roger
Bowers has provided a variety of early sixteenth–century examples both of this practice and of
attempts at its prevention. In 1514 the dean and chapter of Lincoln Cathedral secured royal
letters granting their choir exemption from poaching (except by the Chapel Royal) and in
1523–4 the choir of St Botolphs, Boston (Lincolnshire), paid 26s 8d to be spared the impress*
ment of their singing boys for Cardinal Wolsey's chapel.৳
Thus the permissions to take up boys for St Paul's choir, received both by Sebastian Westcote
and his successor, Thomas Giles, represent conventional practice (see pp 135, 160) –as does
the poaching of one of Westcotes boys in 1575, revealed by a note in the acts of the privy
council (see p 148). The fullest account of this practice however comes from a Star Chamber
suit brought in December 1601. In it Henry Clifton, father of an impressed boy, charged that
not only his son but also seven other named boys had been commandeered to be part of the
new Blackfriars acting company. Although at least two of the boys had been Paul's choristers,
Clifton charged that all had been impressed for their acting ability and were in noe way able
or fitt for singinge (see p 174). The historic practice of stealing boy musicians for distinguished
choirs seems thus to underlie the later, similar theft of boy actors.
Parishes
Parish records in London survive abundantly and reveal a rich variety of drama.s The capital is
traditionally said to have had 108 parish churches before the Great Fire. That listing, followed

DRAMA, MUSIC, AND CEREMONIAL CUSTOMS
xxiv
here, incorporates those parishes lying in both London and Middlesex: St Andrew Holborn
St Botolph without Aldgate, St Botolph without Bishopsgate, St Dunstan in the West, St Giles
without Cripplegate, and St Sepulchre (see Appendix 7).2 London's population in its twenty*
five wards has been discussed above (see pp xiii–xiv). An important element in assessing the
citys size, the 1540 responses to the Chantries Act, provides figures on parish size as well. At
mid–century the majority had 200 to 400 communicants while the outlying parishes were
considerably larger.
Financial records earlier than 1642– churchwardens accounts and vestry minutes – exist for
eighty out of the capital's 108 churches, roughly three–quarters of London's parishes.€ Our
knowledge of parish drama however is dependent on the earliest of the parish records since with
the accession of Elizabeth the traditional, religiously based dramatic practices were no longer
part of parish life in London. After 1558 parish boy bishops, hocking, maying, and Palm Sunday
drama disappear, and the only witness of parish–based plays are two rentals of parish space:
St Xatharine Cree's churchyard in 1565 and St Botolph without Aldersgate's former fraternity
hall for a decade ending in 1567.
It is thus in a smaller, earlier group of records that we must look for traces of ceremony and
theatre: in the pre–Elizabethan accounts surviving in twenty–seven parishes –one quarter of
London's total. Supplementary information is found in the Edwardian inventories produced
by most parishes when, between 1548 and 1552, they sold their vestments and other posses*
sions connected with religious ceremonial.2 Forty–three such inventories survive, from close
to half the 108 London parishes, and twenty–nine come from churches where we do not have
the more complete record provided by accounts. The conclusion is inescapable: if we had
accounts from the parishes where we have only lists of goods, our notion of parish playing
would be realistically fuller.
A group of thirteen parishes whose records originate before I500 provides the earliest glimpse
of parish life. The first record comes from St Mary at Hill around 1422 followed by St Petei
Westcheap in 1431. Five parishes have records from the 1450s (All Hallows Barking and St
Nicholas Shambles, 1452: St Andrew Hubbard, 1454: All Hallows on London Wall and St
Michael Cornhill, 1455), while the records of the remaining six begin at various points in the
second half of the century (All Hallows Staining, St Botolph without Aldersgate, St Dunstan
in the East, St Martin Orgar, St Stephen Coleman Street, and St Stephen Walbrook).
Several quasi–dramatic forms appear in these pre–1500 accounts and continue later, in other
records. The boy bishop is found almost from the beginning of the accounts in 1431 and 1432
and earlier a child's mitre is listed in an isolated inventory of around 1400 from St Martin
Ludgate. The most substantial evidence of this immensely popular practice however appears
not in the parish accounts but in the Edwardian inventories descriptions of small copes and
mitres. In addition a dramatized, symbolic liturgy of Palm Sunday involved the rental of wigs
and costumes and the construction of platforms for parishioners who played the prophets
celebrating Christ's ]erusalem entry. Hocking (1457) and maying (1458) each occur in six
parishes. Display and festivity were provided as well by portable pageants used as sets for both
human and artificial figures, by constructed figures of giants, and by parish–owned stores
of costumes.

DRAMA, MUSIC, AND CEREMONIAL CUSTOMS
xxv
THE LITURGICAL CALENDAR
The Boy Bishop
The liturgical year's first dramatic celebration offered a ceremony of inversion centred around
the boy bishop, as costumed choirboys took the places of their masters on either St Nicholas
Day (6 December) or Holy Innocents Day (28 December). The feast permitted reversal of
the familiar clerical hierarchy, licensed some degree of disorder, and encouraged recognition
of skill in music and Latinity– perhaps the reason ]ohn Colet encouraged the practice in his
statutes for St Paul's school.S By Colet's time the ceremony had been established at the cathedra
for over 300 years, since it is mentioned in the statutes of Ralph de Diceto, c 1180–1200 (see
p 14). Its earliest material witness is the white mitre given to the cathedral's boy bishop by
]ohn Belemeyns, a prebendary, and listed in an inventory of 1245 (see p 15).5 The same
inventory also mentions twenty–eight boys copes and mantles, designated for the feasts of
fools and Innocents.
The boy bishop ceremonies originated in cathedrals and monasteries, their mocking inversions
springing out of a close living community of men and boys. Tet these practices are also very
widely found in London parishes. Fifty–two parishes, about half of London's total, possessed
the vestments necessary for the boy bishop observance. Often the record is unequivocal, as with
the ownership of a mitre, but even if the less clear records are removed (copes for children might
indicate only the presence of a boys choir) thirty–seven parishes remain –a third of the total of
108 London parishes.2 Considering the losses of documents the number was almost certainly
higher and perhaps as many as two₯thirds of London parishioners enjoyed these Christmas₯time
revels in their churches and neighbourhoods.
The earliest parish record comes from a St Martin Ludgate inventory around 1400, about
a century and a half after Belemeyns gift to Paul's boy bishop and perhaps two centuries after
de Diceto's statutes. It lists two albs, two amices, and a cope for St Nicholas, plus a mitre
garnished with l£૱૱res de le৳¥s & Marie de perill (see p 23). In 1431 and 1432 St Peter
Westcheap and St Mary at Hill list similar items: two children's copes and a mitre at the latter,
the same at the former, plus a chasuble, tunicle, and three albs for children (see p 24). Copes
or mantles were widely used as choir habits on feasts, both by men and boys, and were worn
by clergy and laity:૱ At St Martin the two childrens albs probably dressed the boys accompanying
the bishop, who wore the cope and the pearl mitre. Taken together St Martin's possessions,
like the cathedral's inventory, allow us to see a liturgically costumed boy bishop escorted by
other costumed children. The most continuous fifteenth–century references to this custom come
from St Mary at Hill (1431–2, 1485–6, 1480–00) and St Nicholas Shambles (1468–0,
1476–3, c 1400).
Red was frequently the colour for these garments, since although St Nicholas was not a martyr,
the Holy Innocents were. St Michael Cornhill owned a vestment somtyme for .S. Nycolas
byshop for A chyld of red velvet w€t฿ orfews of ye apostles (see p 108). Mitres abound. Indeec
it is possible to trace the three types distinguished by liturgists: the precious mitre (St Sepulchre
had one garnished with silver, pearls, and stones): the golden mitre (St Antholin's was made

DRAMA, MUSIC, AND CEREMONIAL CUSTOMS
xxvi
of needlework of gold and one of St Peter Westcheap's three mitres was cloth of silver): and
the simple mitre (St Peter Cornhill had one of white silk).
The parish–by–parish sale of religious goods between 1548 and 1552 in response to doctrinal
changes shows how widespread ownership of this clothing was. Because several parishes have
both accounts (which record their purchase) and Edwardian lists (which record their sale), it is
occasionally possible to identify the small garments bought and made earlier as those disposed
of in mid–century. In 1521–2 the wardens of St Peter Westcheap had purchased material for
the bishop's robe, two yards of red Bristol cloth, plus sarcenet for the hood, and had paid for
making the costume, spending in all the considerable amount of I0s 6d for materials and
construction (see p 60). It seems likely that when in 1548–0 the parish sold its St Nicholas
coat for 20d, that is, less than 2s, it was the same piece described with so much detail in their
earlier accounts (see p 112).
Provincial parish records do not register such enthusiasm for the boy bishop. In part, at
least, London's wide investment in this custom may be explained by the cathedral's presence
and its recognized status as a touchstone of liturgical practice. It may be too that the high
incidence of boy bishops in the capital is connected, either as cause or effect, with London's
development of parish childrens choirs (see Appendix I0). Since eleven parishes register the
presence of boy bishops between 1400 and 1500, we might wonder whether the parish boys
choirs now visible only from the end of the fifteenth century might have been present earlier.
The surprisingly widespread nature of the custom probably lies behind London's 1538
mayoral injunction against it, which places the site of disorder in the parish (see Appendix 3)
The order complains of the gret cost£৳ & charg£৳ of many honest p£৲sones in making Bankett£৳
to the Clerk£৳ & priest£৳ but also to the great dysquyeting of the said p$৲ysshyon£৲৳. The
aldermen are commanded to see that parish staff, curates, parsons, and parish clerks, doo not
deck tryme or sett fourth any chyld, nether to be sett in any place w€t₽in the churche nor to
goo abowte the p$৲yshe. St Nicholas bishop was a powerful symbol of traditional belief and
practices (Machyn calls it ye old ffassyon) and in the royal suppression of these practices that
followed the mayor's command three years later, in 1541, it is possible to see the reformers
distaste for this excrescence on the liturgy, its playful foolishness expressing all too well the old
religion's impurities. Such a position may lie behind the civic command as well, yet the mayoral
language stresses the customs nuisance quotient, for which the parish clergy are held responsible
at a moment when liturgical reform had not yet firmly taken hold.
Dueen Mary revived the custom in 1554 about a month before its December observance:
on 13 November Bishop Edmund Bonner issued a permission to all priests of his London
diocese. Machyn, the only witness, says the permission was rescinded, but that the ceremony
was observed in divers Parishes, then, and again in 1556. Nuisance, or even crime, is invoked
again in the latter year when the conservative Dr Francis Mallett, master of St katharines
Hospital, asked a reforming parishioner, Gertrude Crokhay, why she refused the boy bishop
entrance. Crokhay replied, Twas a frayd of them that came with hym to haue had my purse
cut by them. For I haue harde of men robbed by S. Nicolas clerks (see p 136). Lest we think
this is merely Crokhays Protestantism speaking we should note that three years earlier, in
1553, Thomas Wilson's A৲૱£ of R฿£૱¢৲€₯ describes this class: they are no Churchmen, they are

DRAMA, MUSIC, AND CEREMONIAL CUSTOMS
xxvii
maisterlesse men, or rather S. Nicolas Clarkes that lacke liuing. S As in the 1538 civic order two
decades before, Crokhay's reply charges the old ceremonies with the production of disorder.
Palm Sunday Prophet:
London parochial involvement with this elaborated festival liturgy is extensive, though Palm
Sunday prophets were not nearly so popular as were boy bishops.s€ Thirteen London parishes,
about half of those having pre–1558 records, embellished their Palm Sunday liturgy with
procession and with dramatization of the liturgical texts, in which boys and adult men played
(and sang) the Old Testament prophets. In the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries parishes rented
costumes, wigs, and props for prophets, and paid to build scaffolds for them to stand on.s The
full presentation of what nevertheless remained a liturgical celebration might even include a
scenic backdrop: St Margaret, Southwark, possessed a stained, or painted, cloth of [erusalem
for use on Palm Sunday. A lost payment for playing the prophet has been cited from 1451
the earliest reference (see p 27), while records of Palm Sunday carpentry survive from 1486 to
1400 (and perhaps earlier), but the celebration's heyday came in the early sixteenth century
and it continued until Elizabeth's accession. 6
The Sarum liturgy for Palm Sunday was indeed quasi৳mimetic. Before mass and after the
blessing of palms the priest, followed by choir and people, made his way outside to the church*
yard cross, where the deacon read the gospel account of Christ's entry into ]erusalem. & This
procession of priest and parishioners represented the crowd welcoming Christ to the city. As
the concluding words of the gospel were uttered, Blessed is he who comes in the name of the
Lord, a second procession, carrying the sacrament and symbolizing Christ and the disciples,
emerged from the church and met the first one. At this moment when Christ and the crowd
met symbolically, three men standing on scaffolds– the prophets– sang three short texts
of welcome.
Four parishes rented costumes (called either garments or raiment) for the adult prophets:
Sts Dunstan in the East and West, St Mary at Hill, and St Mary Magdalen Milk Street (which
mounted a more complex production on Palm Sunday that will be discussed below). St Magnus
was wealthy enough to own the costumes it used. Under Edward vi it listed fyve garment£৳
for p৲¢phett£৳ w€t฿ fyve collers & V crownet£৳ and v heres thereto belonging./ At St Mary
Woolnoth and St Michael le Cuerne the pynnes to dresse profitt£৳ show there were costumed
prophets in these parishes as well, although their costumes were likely to have been liturgical
vestments, adjusted in this standard way.
Three parishes rented wigs (hairs) for prophets: St Mary at Hill, St Peter Westcheap, and
St Stephen Walbrook (1522 to 1534). St Stephen got its wigs in 1531 from ]ohn English, one
of Henry V11's players at least since 1494, sometimes the troupes leader, and paid as a member
until 1531, the year in which St Stephen rented from him.ss In addition St Margaret Lothbury
in 1540 sold iij heres (see p 112).
St Andrew Hubbard and St Mary at Hill rented Palm Sunday hangings from the royal
wardrobe in the Tower. These hangings were a staple decorative element on public occasions
and were sometimes rented by parishes for royal entries. That parishes drew on royal stores

5
DRAMA, MUSIC, AND CEREMONIAL CUSTOMS
xxviii
to augment their theatrical resources is not surprising, but the borrowings could go in the
other direction as well, as when the office of the revels borrowed frames from St Sepulchres
parish. The movement of liturgy toward drama was intensified by the parish purchase of
identifying scrolls, boards, or labels with the prophets names (St Dunstan in the West, St Martin
Orgar, St Mary at Hill, St Mary Magdalen Milk Street, and St Stephen Walbrook).
The Palm Sunday celebration at St Mary Magdalen Milk Street, a well–off parish with a
substantial number of mercer parishioners, was more elaborate than other displays of prophetic
witnesS. Its expenditure of Ss in 1535–6 for prophets garments is substantial: more typical
would be I2d or 16d. The play's scope was larger as well because it included not only Christs
[erusalem entry (there were payments for the man who led God's horse) but also the Crucifixion
(payments for Longinus, the blind centurion, and for liquid that ran out of the cross).0 What
Milk Street offered was a Passion play, one not freestanding but springing out of the liturgy of
Palm Sunday and moving forward through the events of Christ's death.
Payment for carpentry precedes the other expenses for wigs, costumes, and props, and Palm
Sunday playing may come as early as 1468 if St Michael Cornhill's two hurdles (supporting
cross–bars) for stages for the church wall were really intended to hold Palm Sunday prophets
(see p 30). St Andrew Hubbard's payments for frame and workmanship over the church door
(1485–6, 1452–3) are later elucidated by St Mary at Hill's 1525 payment for a quarter of
board for the frame over the north door p$t is for pe p৲¢fett£৳ on palmesonday.
Palm Sunday dramatic celebrations, as revealed by parish carpentry, thus may begin in the
last quarter of the fifteenth century and they run through spring 1546. Henry VII1 died in
]anuary 154677: after a hiatus under Edward, Mary's reinstitution of traditional liturgical
celebrations like processions and holy days, on 20 December 1553 and 4 March 1553/4, was
carried out with alacrity.: That spring St Dunstan in the West bought three bills (labels) for
prophets and St Mary Woolnoth purchased girdles, needles, thread, and palms, but the celebra*
tions disappeared again under Elizabeth
In the late fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries this symbolism supported a particular
religious point of view, as the issue of the eucharistic real presence became increasingly contro
versial. The Palm Sunday ceremonies were strongly associated with traditional belief in the
sacrament. In them the displayed host was identified with the historic Christ of Palm Sunday
and was greeted, reverenced, and welcomed with music and spectacle. These practices developed,
in London at least, when that belief was under attack, and in their musical, dramatized, litur
gical display of the sacrament they represent the response of orthodoxy to a theological challenge
Other Parish Plays
On other occasions besides Palm Sunday the tendency of the liturgy to dramatic realization can
be seen. In 1539/40 St Mary Woolnoth rented hairs, garlands, and lamps for five virgins to play
on All Hallows Day, and it may be that the parable of the wise and foolish virgins (Mt 13. 1–25)
was thought appropriate for celebration on this feast of the saved (see p 96). When Mary was
on the throne in 1557 Machyn recorded a Passion play at the Greyfriars, but whether it was
liturgical or not is unclear, and in the same year St Olave Silver Street (Monkwell Street)

DRAMA, MUSIC, AND CEREMONIAL CUSTOMS
xxix
offered a Stage–Play, of a goodly Matter– which might be either a religious or a secular play
(see p 136).
PARISH CUSTOMS
Hocking
Six London parishes show receipts for hocking collections: at four of them the practice begar
in the fifteenth century. These collections provided both fun and money for the parish on the
second Monday and Tuesday after Easter. On alternate days the women and men stopped and
bound each other in order to extract playful fines.*
Civic sources predate the parish records and show that hocking was being practised in
London from the beginning of the fifteenth century. Between 1406 and 1438 the citys Letter
Books I and X include fifteen injunctions issued by the mayor and aldermen against hocking
in this context a rowdy, public disturbance. The brief, formulaic character of the commands,
coming as they do every two or three years and forbidding citizens to force others to join in
hocking, speaks of the routine maintenance of order. Strangely the remaining fifteenth–century
Letter Book L (through 1457) does not mention this practice (though a reference from 1446
forbids hocking during Margaret of Anjou's arrival in London). Hence it may be that the
earliest surviving mentions of hocking under parish auspices in the 1450s signal a change in
its function if not its nature: the domestication of disorder and the taming of its character
under institutional supervision. As katherine French points out the rise of hocking came at
a point when the parish was increasing its influence in late medieval society.76 Although it
was preceded by a 1450 letter condemning hocking, sent from Bishop [ohn Carpenter of
Worcester to the priests and people of his diocese, and by the 1455 occurrence of hocking at
St Margaret, Southwark, the record in 1457 from All Hallows on London Wall (two years after
their accounts begin) is certainly one of the earliest instances of parish hocking anywhere.
All Hallows on London Wall's Hocktide receipts run irregularly from 1457–8 to 1528–0.
Both men and women collected here in 1457–8 and in 1500–11. But the record also provides
instances of wives gathering alone and it gives the names of three women who handed over
Hocktide collections. Since all three were the wives of wardens it appears that their husbands
positions gave them a degree of official responsibility for gathering. In 1457–8 money was
received from Botelers wyf whose husband William was a warden in that year and served
both an earlier and a later term of office. The wife of Simon Pratt appears as a collector in
1477–8: her husband was a warden then and would be again in 1482–5. ]ohn Webbe served
in an undated year between 1512 and 1528, when his wife turned in a substantial sum in hock
money. That the responsibility for the parish's financial well–being was shared by this group
of men and women (and that it was not confined only to Hocktide gatherings) is shown
by an All Hallows on London Wall account entry for 1480–2 which notes that over 21s
were received in Gaderyng of almes toward the chirch werks by the churchwardens and
their wives.*
Hocking at St Nicholas Shambles is illustrated by a single reference from 1464–5, when

DRAMA, MUSIC, AND CEREMONIAL CUSTOMS
xxx
the large sum of 20s 4d was received from a variety of sources including maye money and
hoctydemoney (see p 20). All Hallows Stainings exclusively female hocking is recorded in the
last decade of the fifteenth century and the first decade of the sixteenth. Receipts in 1508–10
show that the wives of this parish collected in the hystrete, that is, in the broad street just north
of their church leading to Aldgate (the present Fenchurch Street), and in blankechapulton,
a liberty east of the church that in the fifteenth century had developed into one of the havens
where debtors, aliens, and foreigners could practise their trades immune from crast supervision.
As a reward for their work in 1451–2 the parish underwrote a wives dinner which cost over
8s, a women's festival at which meat, cheese, and bread were bought to provide a drynkyng
with harp music for the triumphant collectors (see p 37). St Mary at Hill paid much less for
a similar feast in 1406–7, 1467–8, 1458–0, and 1409–1500, spending between Dd and 16d
each year
Although St Andrew Hubbard's accounts begin in 1454, the first hocking entry comes only
in 1521–2 and the second in 1528–8: the collectors are female or unspecified. Such late and
scanty evidence in the accounts leads Clive Burgess to suggest that hocking funds might
ordinarily have been entrusted to the care of senior members of the parish other than church.
wardens, and to imply that hocking was probably more frequent at St Andrew than these
records can reveal.s
St Mary at Hill's accounts provide the fullest picture of the practice, showing a remarkably
persistent run of hocking receipts for over thirty years, from 1406–7 to 1527–8, with both
male and female collectors. Usually the women's receipts for Hock Monday are two, three,
four, or even five times that of the men's for Hock Tuesday, as in 1504–5 when the women
gathered over 33s, the men over 8s, or in 1511–12 when 20s was the women's total, versus
4s for the men. As at All Hallows on London Wall some women's names are given: in 1522
Goodwife Wall appears when her husband ]ohn Wall was in office, and later the wife of Robert
Averey, a warden in 1522–3 and 1523–4, is mentioned. Amounts as large as 18s or 20s were
sometimes kept back for a year or two, and summonses to turn in the gains had to be issued,
as in February 1520/I when the accounts carry the following memo: It£m that the money that
is gadered on hokmonday And hoktweysday for ij yer£৳ p$t is past be called in to pis Acompte
(see p 57).
These payments show the contribution hocking could make to parish liturgical and ceremo
nial life. On 13 February 1521/2 St Mary at Hill agreed that five separate parcels of money,
four of them hock collections, would go toward the organs. Three of these parcels were for
unspecified amounts, but two were for Ss and for 13S. In 1521/2 the parishioners then paid
10s 8d for the organs and their transportation, besides that was gaderid, which suggests that
it was largely hocking that provided the new organs.
St Mary's hocking concluded with a careful accounting, dated 28 April 1528, of money
collected in that year and the previous one. The total was something over E4. Their dis
continuing of this practice –or at least its absence from the records– came at exactly the same
time as that of All Hallows on London Wall and St Andrew Hubbard. In all three parishes
spring 1528 was the last occurrence of hocking, perhaps because the 1520s were a time of
unusual economic deprivation which saw in London three visitations of the plague as well.৳

DRAMA, MUSIC, AND CEREMONIAL CUSTOMS
xxxi
One final example comes from Mary's reign: at St Botolph without Aldgate in 1554–5 certain
women of the parish gathered the large sum of 20s which was spent on a Crosse clothe.
Hocking has traditionally been classified as rural or at least regional. Hutton says that it was
not much used in the capital, its classic home being a provincial town.8 Evidence for the
custom at these six London parishes however establishes hocking as definitely urban as well
Though St Botolph without Aldgate was situated at the citys eastern edge and All Hallows on
London Wall on its northern wall, the other four parishes are not peripheral ones. St Nicholas
Shambles lay just north of St Paul's Cathedral while St Mary at Hill and St Andrew Hubbard
were located in the city centre very close to each other, with All Hallows Staining not far off.s৳
Maying
]ohn Stow's wellknown description of London's maying sets it firmly within the parish and
provides it with maypoles, martial displays, and morris dancers in the day, and plays and bon–
fires in the evening (see pp 51–2). Stow's tone is antiquarian like that of the 1584 collections
of St Andrew Holborn's churchwarden, Thomas Bentley, which similarly stress parochial
community and conviviality. Maying in the parish accounts appears both early and late but
not widely. Based on references from St Andrew Hubbard (1459–61, perhaps 1510–12) and
from St Nicholas Shambles (1458, 1463, 1465) it seems mainly a fifteenth–century affair
though in 1535–6 St Botolph without Aldersgate received 4s 4d from children who made
a May game for the church, and Stows story of the reformers destruction of St Andrew
Undershaft's maypole in 1540 is familiar (see pp 114–15). It is the 1550s however, reflected in
Henry Machyn's diary, that produce a cascade of May references. Anne Lancashire has suggesteo
that in this decade following the discontinuance of the Midsummer Watch in the 1540s.
elaborate May games may have become Watch substitutes, since they share the same elements:
guns, drums, morris dancers, and giants.5 Later in 1500 the parish clerk of St Botolph without
Aldgate tells the tragic story of a young man who died of gunpowder burns from a May game
not a parishioner but fatally injured within the parish (see p 161).
Robin Hood games, often a staple of May celebration, were always associated with a con*
servative religious and social position. When around 1535 Sir Richard Morrison urged Henry vII
to sponsor anti–papal plays, Morrison suggested these should replace the lewd and ribald plays
of Robin Hood found everywhere.5 Conversely when Bishop Stephen Gardiner, about ten years
later, told the players of London to stick to plays of Robin Hood and Little ]ohn, he meant
they should offer traditional inoffensive amusements as opposed to the reforming plays
recommended by Morrison (see p 104). That London parishes hosted Robin Hood plays, or
at least festivities, is confirmed by the Edwardian inventory of Holy Trinity the Less, which
lists fifteen Robin Hood coats (see p 123).
Pageants
An important part of parish festivities, though less firmly tied to a particular occasion in the
liturgical year, were parish pageants. The London records associate them with three occasions
